newsitem.title: UK: FORECAST - Ladbroke H1 profit set to rise.
newsitem.headline: FORECAST - Ladbroke H1 profit set to rise.

text.p: A strong performance from its UK hotels and a recovery in retail betting revenues should help leisure group Ladbroke to increase interim pre-tax profits to around 65-70 million stg next Thursday, analysts said.
Ladbroke had pre-tax, pre-exceptional profit of 56.5 million stg in the first six months of 1995.
"The results should not be disappointing. They will benefit from a strong UK hotel environment, both in London and the provinces," said one analyst.
"The one weaker point could be the continental European hotels," he added.
Ladbroke chairman John Jackson told shareholders in May that profit before tax in the first four months of 1996 was ahead of the corresponding period in 1995.
Hotel performance in the UK was particularly strong with revenue per available room up 16 percent in London, he said.
Ladbroke's Hilton International hotels were reported to be performing well but trading in continental Europe "remained under pressure".
Jackson said talks were taking place with Hilton Hotels Corp of the U.S., on reuniting the Hilton brand but added that these were at an early stage.
Hilton Hotels has the rights to the name in the U.S., while Ladbroke uses it in other parts of the world.
The betting and gaming division has been badly hit over the past 18 months by the success of the National Lottery, operated by the Camelot consortium.

Ladbroke has said that the outlook for 1996 is better thanks to cost-cutting and a one percentage point reduction in betting duty to 6.75 percent announced in last November's budget. The reduction took effect on March 1.

Ladbroke's Vernons football pools division has also suffered from the effects of the Lottery. Pools betting duty was cut by five percentage points to 27.5 percent last December in a bid to boost the industry.
Operating profit from hotels was 150.2 million stg in 1995 while betting and gaming contributed 58.1 million.
Pre-tax profit on ordinary activites in 1995 totalled 121.3 million stg, down from 128.5 million in 1994.
